section.title: Introduction
section.para: Textual scholars have at their disposal an increasing number of digital tools and technologies to examine the genesis of a literary work. We can model or capture a wide variety of (complex) textual phenomena, and our analysis of them, in a digital transcription.Define "digital transcription": this ranges from plain text to MS Word to TEI/XML. Suggestion: "A 'digital transcription' can be anuything from plain text to MS Word and TEI/XML. Unless explicated otherwise, this paper uses the term (digital) transcription to refer to a TEI/XML transcription." This transcription can subsequently be processed by various tools for further analysis or visualisation. Simply put, transcribing and processing text are forms of translation, from one sign system to another. Making a transcription is generally understood to be a critical act of editorial interepretation , and we can say the same about text processing: a tool performs multiple operations on a text, each operation involving a transformation of the data. It follows that before we can influence/customize a tool, it is necessary to understand its workings and the transformations a text undergoes. This, in turn, can lead to a more fitting/adequate/suitable framework to investigate/model a text.

An interesting area of study, and one that poses some particularly challengeing issues, is the automated collation of modern manuscripts. This type of documents often contains (heavy) revisions and complex sites of textual variation which are challengeing to adequately capture and process in TEI/XML. In short, the genetic orientation to text examines a text's development and the creative processes that propegate literary invention[REF Shillingsburg and Van Hulle 2015]. As the genetic orientation studies the processes of writing and revising, it is vital that revisions are included in the collation process, so that researchers can study both the revision within one document and the revision across document borders. The present paper discusses how human interaction with collation algorithms benefits this kind of research. This issue has been previously explored in [REF to paper ESTS 2016], focusing on one characteristic of textual revisions - substitutions - where the word order is of importance. The TEI/XML transcriptions of the modern manuscripts of Samuel Beckett and Raymond Brulez serve as case studies.
